questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with dysphagia and regurgitation. Barium swallow showed the following picture. Weakness of which of the following muscles predisposes to the given condition​?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a pulsion diverticulum on the barium swallow is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It originates through Killian's dehiscence, which is a site of weakness present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts:

  1. Upper part - thyropharyngeus, made of oblique fibres.
  2. Lower part - cricopharyngeus, made of transverse fibres.

Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the longitudinal muscle of the oesophagus.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Pharyngo-esophageal diverticula

questions.text: A patient presents with odynophagia and trismus. Examination of the oral cavity reveals that the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental area is tender with a woody-hard feel. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above patient with odynophagia, trismus, swollen floor of the mouth with a woody-hard feel, and the tongue being pushed up and back is likely to have Ludwig's angina. The most common cause of Ludwig's angina is dental infections. 

Ludwig's angina is the infection of the floor of the mouth. The submandibular space is present between the mucus membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia that extends between the hyoid bone and the mandible on the other side. The mylohyoid muscle divides this space into the sublingual space (above the mylohyoid) and the submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid). 

Dental infections account for 80-90% of cases of Ludwig's angina. Infections of the premolars can spread to sublingual space, while infections of molar teeth can spread to the submaxillary space. The infections are usually polymicrobial. Alpha-hemolytic streptococci, staphylococci, and Bacteroides groups are commonly associated.

Patients present with difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) and trismus. Examination of the oral cavity will reveal that the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental and submandibular space becomes swollen, tender, and has a woody-hard feel. Severe infection can lead to a threatened airway due to displacement of the tongue. 

It is treated by systemic antibiotics, incision and drainage of the abscess, and tracheostomy if the airway is threatened. 

Complications of this condition include the spread of infection to the parapharyngeal space, retropharyngeal space, and the mediastinum, airway obstruction, septicemia, and aspiration pneumonia. 

Below image shows Ludwig's angina

Other options: 

Option A: Acute tonsilitis can lead to peritonsillar abscess (quinsy). It is characterized by severe throat pain, fever with chills and rigors, odynophagia, hot potato voice, and foul breath. The examination will reveal edema of tonsils, tonsillar pillars, soft palate, and uvula. The tonsils might not be visible due to edema of the tonsillar pillars. The uvula is pushed to the opposite side.

Option B: Submandibular sialadenitis is a less common cause of Ludwig's angina. 

Option D: Mycobacterium tuberculosis causes a chronic retropharyngeal abscess. It presents with dysphagia, fluctuating swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A patient with HIV comes with complaints of dysphagia and odynophagia. He is not on any medications. Examination of the oral cavity shows a normal mucosa. What will you give as the the next best step?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an HIV patient not on treatment presenting with dysphagia and odynophagia is suggestive of esophagitis. The common cause of esophagitis in an immunosuppressed patient is Candida; hence, next step for this patient is giving oral fluconazole.

Esophagitis due to Candida albicans is common in immunocompromised patients taking steroids, chemotherapy, and HIV. The most common symptoms are dysphagia, odynophagia, and retrosternal chest pain. Odynophagia is a hallmark of esophageal candidiasis. Thrush in the oral cavity or throat may be seen, but not in all cases, and endoscopy would show numerous white plaques. 

Patients who are immunosuppressed and have symptoms of odynophagia or dysphagia can be empirically treated with a course of antifungal therapy. Unlike oropharyngeal candidiasis, esophageal candidiasis should always be treated with systemic agents and not topical agents hence topical nystatin can be ruled out (option B).

The other organisms that cause esophagitis in immunocompromised persons are cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes. If no improvement in symptoms is seen after 72 hours of starting antifungal therapy, then an upper endoscopy should be performed. Oral valacyclovir and ganciclovir (options C and D) can be used for the treatment of herpes and cytomegalovirus infection, respectively, after being confirmed by endoscopy and biopsy and not treated empirically.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

questions.text: A 72-year-old female patient presented to the hospital with complaints of difficulty swallowing and generalised weakness for 4 months. Peripheral smear revealed the following and an esophagography was done as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with microcytic hypochromic anemia and characteristic esophagogram is suggestive of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. 

Plummer-Vinson syndrome/Paterson–Kelly syndrome has a triad of:

  • Post-cricoid webs
  • Dysphagia
  • Iron-deficiency anemia

The webs are made up of fibrovascular stroma and esophageal epithelium. Glossitis, angular stomatitis, koilonychia are also associated with this condition.

Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic-hypochromic blood picture and barium esophagography or esophagogastroduodenoscopy(EGD) will help detect post-cricoid webs. 

Treatment includes correcting the iron-deficiency anemia which may improve dysphagia and pain. Esophageal bougies can be used during upper endoscopy to dilate the post-cricoid webs and allow normal swallowing and passage of food.

Complications include the risk of perforation during dilatation and also malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma. 

The image below shows endoscopic appearance of post-cricoid web.

questions.text: A farmer presents with difficulty swallowing and jaw tightening. He gives a history of getting his finger jammed in the rustic gate a few days ago. He gives no history of previous tetanus immunization. After evaluation, he was diagnosed with tetanus. The release of which of the following neurotransmitters is affected by the toxin responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Tetanus toxin affects the release of GABA.

Tetanus toxin escapes normal lysosomal degradation and crosses the synapse to the GABA-ergic presynaptic inhibitory interneuron terminals. The toxin blocks the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid) across the synaptic cleft. This blockage of the inhibitory neurotransmitters causes spastic paralysis.

questions.text: Consider the following barium swallow finding in a patient of dysphagia. Manometry in this patient will show_________

choices.text: Decreased amplitude of oesophageal peristalsis <30 mmHg
Peristaltic oesophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal

questions.solution:
The barium swallow image shows corkscrew oesophagus seen in diffuse oesophageal spasm. Manometry in diffuse oesophageal spasm will show simultaneous multipeak contractions >120mmHg.

Diffuse oesophageal spasm:

  • Barium swallow: Corkscrew or rosary-bead esophagus, segmental spasm or pseudodiverticulosis appearance is seen. It is due to the presence of tertiary contractions. It is indicative of advanced disease.
  • Manometry findings: Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec). These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows. There is intermittent normal peristalsis.

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text: A 6-year-old unimmunized boy from the rural area complains of difficulty swallowing. On examination, the below finding is seen. What is false regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: All cases should be reported to local and state health departments
Specific antitoxin is the mainstay of treatment
All case contacts are closely monitored for illness through 7-day incubation period
Immunized case contacts need not receive antimicrobial prophylaxis

questions.solution:
The image shows a Pseudomembrane in an unimmunized boy, suggesting a diagnosis of Diphtheria. In which, all case contacts should be treated with prophylactic antimicrobial therapy irrespective of immunization status. All the other options are true.

Diphtheria:

  • Causative agent: Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Carriers are the most common causes of infection. Immunization does not prevent the carrier state.
  • The regulation of toxin production in the bacterium is partially controlled by iron, thus making it an important prerequisite for toxin production.
  • Mode of infection: Droplets through the respiratory tract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites.

Clinical features:

  • Respiratory tract diphtheria: 
    • The commonest type of diphtheria
    • Thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx. Dislodging of the membrane may cause bleeding.
    • Underlying soft tissue edema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance.
    • Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue edema and airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane.
  • Cutaneous diphtheria:
    • An indolent, non-progressive infection characterized by a superficial, ecthyma-like, non-healing ulcer with a gray-brown membrane.
  • Infection at other sites:
    • Occasionally, it causes mucocutaneous infections at other sites, such as otitis externa, purulent conjunctivitis, and vulvo-vaginitis.

Diagnosis: The culture of the organism from the nose and throat specimens is the gold standard. Demonstration of the toxin by Elek's gel precipitation test. A gram stain or fluorescent antibody test is unreliable.

Complications:

  • Obstruction due to pseudomembrane
  • Myocarditis
  • Polyneuropathy

Recent update:

Diphtheria toxin has been used in the treatment of cancer. Denileukin diftitox (recombinant human interleukin-2 and diphtheria toxin) is the first immunotoxin approved by FDA, for the treatment of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady who had recently undergone a renal transplant comes with complaints of recurrent retrosternal chest pain and swallowing difficulty. As part of her workup, an upper GI endoscopy is done and it appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus lesions appear as serpiginous ulcers in an otherwise normal mucosa, particularly in the distal esophagus.

 

Transplant recipient patients are at higher risk of developing CMV infections. The typical presentation is with complaints that are associated with CMV infections of the other system as well. Complaints that are seen in patients with CMV esophagitis for include

  • Dysphagia & odynophagia
  • Retrosternal pain/ Abdominal pain
  • Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • Hemoptysis

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with dry mouth and difficulty swallowing solid food. Physical examination reveals enlargement of her parotid glands, along with marked dryness of her buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. Which of the following statements is not true about this condition?

choices.text: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal gland is a major target for this disease

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth; difficulty swallowing solid food; and the findings of enlarged parotid gland, dry buccal mucosa, and antibody positivity for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren syndrome. Glomerular lesions are extremely rare in Sjögren syndrome.

Defects of tubular function, including renal tubular acidosis, uricosuria, and phosphaturia, are often seen and are associated histologically with tubulointerstitial nephritis.

Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of this disease, while the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts and the vagina may also be involved. The characteristic decrease in tears and saliva (sicca syndrome) is the result of lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B cells, including plasma cells.

Antibodies detected are:

  • Rheumatoid factor - seen in 75% of patients, whether or not coexisting rheumatoid arthritis is present
  • Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs)
  • SS-A (Ro) - associated with early disease onset, longer disease duration, and extra-glandular manifestations, such as cutaneous vasculitis and nephritis
  • SS-B (La)

These patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas. About 60% of patients have another accompanying autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis, and these patients also have the symptoms and signs of that disorder.

Biopsy of the lip (to examine minor salivary glands) is essential for the diagnosis of Sjögren syndrome.

The image shows an enlargement of the salivary gland with intense lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration with ductal epithelial hyperplasia in the salivary gland.

Note: Mikulicz syndrome is characterized by lacrimal and salivary gland enlargement from any cause, including sarcoidosis, lymphomas, and other tumors.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented with the history of diplopia and dysphagia worsening as the day progresses. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of diplopia due to the weakness in the extraocular muscles, and dysphagia, worsening as the day progresses, is suggestive of myasthenia gravis.

  • The cardinal clinical features of myasthenia gravis includes, weakness and fatigability of muscles.
  • The weakness increases with repeated use or late in the day leading to fatigue and may improve following rest or sleep.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with dysphagia to both solids and liquids, for the past 2 months. Which of the following can present with such symptoms?
questions.solution:
Dysphagia for both solids and liquids suggest motility disorder like Achalasia.

Type of Food Examples
LIQUIDS+SOLIDS
  • Motility disorder: Achalasia
  SOLID
  • Strictures        
  • Ring (Schatzki ring: Episodic dysphagia)     
  • Webs (Episodic dysphagia)        
  • Tumors

Achalasia cardia is caused due to the degeneration of the neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. This degeneration results in the failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) on swallowing.

The patients present with a classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia is present to both solid and liquid foods. As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry.

In contrast, esophageal cancer presents with dysphagia initially to solids and then progresses to liquids over a prolonged course of time.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient is brought to the clinic for evaluation of frequent falls. He also complains of difficulty swallowing, urinary incontinence, and impotence. On examination, gross orthostatic changes in the blood pressure are noted. He has ocular dysmetria, scanning dysarthric speech, and gait ataxia. MRI of the brain shows atrophy of multiple regions of the brain and characteristic findings shown below. Which of the following will be the predominant pathological feature in this patient?

choices.text: Neuronal loss and accumulation of tau-containing neurofibrillary tangles in the frontotemporal regions
Ballooned neurons and astrocytic plaques around the astrocytes in the anterior parietal lobes
Pallor of the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus with Lewy bodies
Atrophy of the cerebellum with alpha-synuclein containing inclusions in the oligodendrocytes

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of multiple system atrophy with predominant cerebellar atrophy (MSA-C subtype). The arrow points to the 'hot cross bun' sign seen in MSA-C. This condition is characterized by atrophy of the cerebellum with alpha-synuclein-containing inclusions in the oligodendrocytes.

Multiple system atrophy:

It is a sporadic disease that affects several functional systems in the brain which is characterized by primary pathology in the glial cells.

The predominant clinical features of MSA-C are cerebellar dysfunction that manifests as gait ataxia, limb ataxia, ataxic dysarthria, and cerebellar disturbances of eye movements which manifests as ocular dysmetria, gaze-evoked nystagmus, or impaired smooth pursuits with the saccadic intrusion. Dysphagia is a prominent symptom and the speech pattern is scanning dysarthria. Autonomic dysfunction includes orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, urinary incontinence, nocturnal enuresis, urinary retention, and hesitancy. Sleep and breathing pattern abnormalities may also be seen. Patients with MSA-P have predominant Parkinsonian features in association with the other features described above. MRI shows a characteristic 'hot cross bun sign'. There will be atrophy of the putamen, pons, and middle cerebellar peduncles.

The pathological features in MSA mimic the clinical presentation of the condition. In this patient with cerebellar dysfunction, there will be atrophy of the cerebellum, including the peduncles, pons, basal pontis, inferior olive of the medulla. The diagnostic glial inclusions are demonstrated in the oligodendrocytes with silver impregnation. They contain alpha-synuclein as well as ubiquitin. Autonomic symptoms are related to cell loss from the catecholaminergic nuclei of the medulla.

Other Options:

questions.text: Over the last 3 months,  an adult man has experienced difficulty swallowing with a feeling of food getting stuck below his throat during meals, postprandial vomiting, and a burning sensation in his chest. His symptoms do not improve on taking proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). A histopathological sample from his upper GI endoscopy is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dysphagia, food impaction, non-responsiveness to PPI therapy, along with histopathology showing eosinophilic infiltrates, is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Adult patients with eosinophilic esophagitis present with impaction of food, dysphagia, vomiting, and symptoms of reflux. Eosinophilic esophagitis should be suspected in patients with heartburn that does not improve with PPIs. Children with this condition present with nausea, vomiting, chest/abdominal pain, and intolerance/aversion to food.

These patients are usually atopic and may have associated conditions like atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, or moderate peripheral eosinophilia.

The cardinal histological feature is large numbers of intraepithelial eosinophils. Abnormal squamous maturation is also apparent. Other features include eosinophilic microabscesses, eosinophils in superficial layers of squamous mucosa, and lamina propria fibrosis. The histopathological appearance is helpful in differentiating eosinophilic esophagitis from GERD, Crohn's, and other causes of esophagitis.

The “feline” esophagus which resembles the appearance of stacked circular rings, strictures, and linear furrows on esophageal endoscopy is typical of eosinophilic esophagitis and is shown below-

 

Barium swallow showing the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus-

 

Treatment includes dietary restrictions of food allergen and topical/systemic corticosteroids.

Other Options-

Option (B): Crohn's disease of the esophagus is considered in the differential diagnosis of esophagitis and histopathological examination is required to confirm the diagnosis. On microscopy, it shows abundant neutrophils that infiltrate and damage the crypt epithelium forming clusters of neutrophils called crypt abscesses. Mucosal architecture is distorted.

Option (C): Reflux esophagitis too can present with heartburn. However, these patients are responsive to PPI treatment (unlike the given scenario). Histopathology showing basal zone hyperplasia and elongation of lamina propria papillae are common. Chronic GERD leads to intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa which is known as Barrett's esophagus.

Option (D): Infectious esophagitis - The most common infectious etiology for esophagitis in debilitated and immunosuppressed patients are herpes simplex virus, cytomegalovirus, and candida esophagitis. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection and from the base of the ulcer in cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

  • HSV causes punched out ulcers with cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies on microscopy.
  • CMV causes shallow ulcerations and characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions on microscopy.
  • Candidiasis, in its most advanced form, is characterized by the adherent, gray-white pseudomembranes.

questions.text: The endoscopy and biopsy of a patient with progressive dysphagia and weight loss suggested a diagnosis of esophageal carcinoma. This patient's barium swallow is most likely to show _____.
questions.solution:
The barium swallow of a patient with esophageal carcinoma is likely to show irregular strictures with shouldered margins.

Esophageal carcinoma is a disease of mid-late adulthood and typically presents with dysphagia. Squamous cell carcinoma usually affects the upper 2/3rd of the esophagus and adenocarcinoma affects the lower 1/3rd. Tobacco and alcohol are the main etiological factors.

Endoscopy is the first-line investigation, and a biopsy is required for diagnosis. Other investigations are usually done to define the extent of local or distant spread. On barium swallow, strictures with an ulcerated, irregular mucosa and shouldered margins are seen, as shown in the image below.

 

Contrast-enhanced CT from neck to pelvis is done to identify hematogenous metastases. Only patients who are suitable for curative therapies should be staged. Locoregional staging is done using endoscopic ultrasonography and laparoscopy.

Other options:

Option B: The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm. 

Option C: A smooth stricture without shouldering in the lower esophagus is suggestive of benign peptic stricture, seen in reflux esophagitis.

Option D: A thin submucosal web that encircles the lumen at the squamocolumnar junction refers to Schatzki’s ring.
 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A woman presented with sudden onset of dysphagia, dysarthria and gait ataxia. MRI revealed an acute infarct in the right dorsolateral medulla. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wallenberg syndrome. The symptoms of dysphagia and dysarthria are due to the involvement of nucleus ambiguus. Ataxia is a feature of inferior cerebellar peduncle involvement.

Option A: Medial medullary syndrome is also known as Dejerine's anterior bulbar syndrome.

Option B: Lateral medullary syndrome is also known as Wallenberg syndrome.

Option C: Medullary tegmental paralysis is also known as Babinski-Nageotte syndrome.

Option D: Midbrain stroke syndrome is also known as Weber syndrome.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

questions.text: The investigation of choice for dysphagia lusoria is _______
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for dysphagia lusoria is CT angiography.

Dysphagia lusoria is dysphagia produced due to compression of the esophagus by a developmental vascular anomaly, often an aberrant right subclavian artery. It arises directly from the aortic arch.

In this condition, the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch instead of branching from the brachiocephalic artery. It then courses behind the oesophagus to supply blood to the right arm. This causes pressure on the oesophagus and results in dysphagia. 

It is diagnosed by CT angiography. A barium swallow shows fixed narrowing of the oesophagus at the level of the aortic arch without mucosal abnormality.

Treatment is surgical repair either by reconstruction or ligation of the aberrant right subclavian artery.

The CECT below shows the origin of the aberrant right subclavian artery (red arrow) causing extrinsic compression of the oesophagus.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is given below. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. Which of the following correctly describes the manometric evaluation of this disorder?

IRP: integrated relaxation pressure
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image showing a bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. It is characterized by high median IRP and absent peristalsis.

Disorders of esophageal motility can be classified as:

Disorders of esophago-gastric junction (EGJ) outflow: elevated IRP

  • Achalasia cardia: elevated IRP and peristalsis absent
  • EGJ outflow obstruction: elevated IRP and peristalsis present

Disorders of peristalsis: normal IRP

  • Absent contractility
  • Distal esophageal spasm
  • Hypercontractile esophagus

Achalasia cardia occurs due to the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus of GIT. During swallowing, the food bolus normally triggers a primary peristaltic wave, which is responsible for carrying the bolus to the stomach. This is accompanied by relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to allow esophageal emptying into the stomach. Achalasia is characterized by a disruption of this normal process. Failure of relaxation of the LES causes an elevated median IRP. Moreover, there is a complete failure of peristalsis. The esophagus becomes progressively more tortuous, leading to megaesophagus.

On upper GI scopy, achalasia can show accumulated saliva or food residue in the lower part of the esophagus, but is often reported normal. Upper GI scopy is an important investigation to rule out a mechanical cause of progressive dysphagia, such as a malignancy. Barium contrast studies show a hold-up of the contrast material in the distal esophagus, giving rise to the bird beak appearance.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with weakness and muscle cramps involving both legs. He also reported difficulty in swallowing food. On examination, he is found to be alert and oriented. Both lower limbs exhibit fasciculations with significant atrophy and extensor plantar reflex. The reflexes in both upper and lower limbs are exaggerated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a type of progressive motor neuron disease. The pathological hallmark is the destruction and death of both upper (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN). Irrespective of what is involved first, eventually ALS will involve both UMN and LMN. The motor neuron disease involving selectively the upper motor neurons is called primary lateral sclerosis, while the one involving selectively the lower motor neurons is called spinomuscular atrophy.

Patients present with insidious onset asymmetric bilateral weakness of the distal part of the lower limbs. There may be a history of cramping, particularly early in the morning. Lower motor neuron death causes muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron involvement presents as exaggerated tendon reflexes and spasticity. Some of the patients also tend to develop frontotemporal dementia. However, the sensory, bowel and bladder functions and cognition is preserved even in the late stages of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute inflammatory demyelinating peripheral neuropathy that occurs 1-3 weeks following an acute infectious process. It results in LMN type of palsy with the absence of deep tendon reflexes. It is also associated with sensory findings like loss of proprioception and autonomic features such as lability of blood pressure. These findings are absent in ALS because only the motor neurons are involved.

Option B: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to abnormalities in the posterior and lateral column function that results in loss of vibration and position sense, progressive spastic weakness, and sensory ataxia. Loss of deep tendon reflexes due to associated peripheral neuropathy can also be seen. However, there is an extensor plantar response due to the involvement of the corticospinal tracts.

Option C: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is a paraneoplastic neuromuscular disorder that presents with proximal muscle weakness, arreflexia, and autonomic dysfunction. In 60% of patients, there may be associated cancer, usually small cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old presents to the OPD following the consumption of a chemical. He complained of a hot burning sensation extending from mouth to stomach and had difficulty in breathing. After 48 hours, the patient passed dark, smoky urine which turned olive green in the urobag. Which of the following is most likely to be consumed by this patient?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario history of burning sensation, difficulty in breathing, and passage of olive green color urine (carboluria) is suggestive of Carbolic acid/ phenol poisoning.

Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Local skin effects: Burning, tingling followed by anesthesia and greyish-white sloughing 
  • Headache, giddiness, tinnitus
  • Vomiting, diarrhea, pain abdomen
  • Pulmonary and laryngeal edema, respiratory failure
  • Muscular spasms, convulsions
  • Collapse
  • A clammy, cold sweating body
  • Pupils dilated
  • Methemoglobinemia 

In carbolic acid poisoning if the patient survives for 48 hrs there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to the oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. 

Management depends on the route of administration.

In case of poisoning through skin absorption

  • Remove the contaminated garments
  • Cleanse the site by mopping with a wet cloth and washing with soap and water
  • Apply olive oil/ methylated spirit/ 10 percent ethyl alcohol, which can prevent further absorption
  • Give normal saline + sodium bicarbonate (I/V- drip)

In case of poisoning through the oral route

  • Perform gastric lavage: Though phenol corrodes the stomach wall, it also hardens it, unlike other corrosive poisons. Hence gastric lavage is performed whenever possible with plenty of lukewarm water containing animal charcoal, olive oil, magnesium or sodium sulfate or saccharated lime, soap solution, 10 percent glycerine, etc. When the lavage is completed, 30 gm of magnesium sulfate or medicinal liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach.
  • Give egg white: Epsom salt/demulcents orally.

Related Pearl: Urine Color caused by certain Toxins

Urine colours

Causes

Olive green colour urine on standing

Carbolic acid

Grey-black

Phenols, cresols

Opaque appearance which settles on standing

Primidone crystals

Orange or orange-red

Rifampicin, iron (especially after giving desferrioxamine)

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with frequent episodes of dysphagia and chest pain. The chest pain is aggravated by having a meal and is relieved by a loud belch. A chest X-Ray showed the following finding. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray findings showing a retrocardiac gas bubble are consistent with the diagnosis of a hiatus hernia.

It is herniation of the stomach fundus or rarely other abdominal contents colon/spleen through a hiatus, usually towards the left side. Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Types of hiatus hernia:

Type 1 or sliding hernia - gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication.

Type 2 or rolling hiatus hernia - gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia. Clinical features include - 

  • Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching
  • Dysphagia
  • Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron’s ulcer) that bleed lead to anemia.

Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modality even in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus.

Type 3 or mixed hiatus hernia - a combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 hiatus hernia - other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon.

CT with oral contrast is the best method of diagnosis of hiatus hernia. It highlights gastric anatomy and also helps to identify other structures involved. Chest X-ray shows an intrathoracic gas bubble.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure
